content: The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" requires the Deputy Director for Management to adopt governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is required to adopt governmentwide standards for program and project management in executive agencies, oversee their implementation, chair the Program Management Policy Council, and establish standards and policies consistent with widely accepted standards. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the establishment of standards, policies, and guidelines for executive agencies, engaging with the private sector to identify best practices, conducting portfolio reviews for high-risk programs, and chairing the Program Management Policy Council. The Deputy Director for Management oversees standards, policies, and guidelines for agencies, engages with the private sector for best practices, conducts portfolio reviews for high-risk programs, and chairs the Program Management Policy Council. Additionally, they establish a 5-year strategic plan for program management. The Deputy Director for Management oversees standards, policies, and guidelines for agencies, conducts portfolio reviews of agency programs, and establishes a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar to existing regulations. The Deputy Director for Management establishes a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar to existing regulations. Deadline for standards, policies, and guidelines is within 1 year of enactment of this Act. The Deputy Director for Management will issue standards, policies, and guidelines within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget will issue regulations within 90 days of issuing standards, policies, and guidelines as required by section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, will issue regulations to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council will be established under Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code. The Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council will be established under Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, with each agency designating a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer. The Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council will be established under Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code. Each agency will designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer, who will implement program management policies and develop strategies for enhancing program roles. The Program Management Improvement Officer of an agency designated under paragraph (1) shall implement program management policies and develop a strategy for enhancing the role of program managers within the agency, including enhanced training opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Officer shall implement policies and develop a strategy for enhancing the role of program managers, including training in relevant competencies and cost containment for large projects. The Program Management Improvement Officer will mentor current and future program managers, improve career paths, encourage recruitment of qualified individuals, collect best practices, and provide templates for program management. The Program Management Improvement Officer aims to mentor program managers, enhance career paths, recruit qualified individuals, collect best practices, and provide templates for program management. The Department of Defense is exempt from these provisions if they are similar to those in chapter 87 of title 10. The Program Management Improvement Officer focuses on mentoring program managers, enhancing career paths, recruiting qualified individuals, collecting best practices, and providing templates for program management. The Department of Defense is exempt from these provisions if they are similar to those in chapter 87 of title 10. The Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics is designated as the Program Management Improvement Officer for the purposes of paragraph (1). A Program Management Policy Council is established in the Office of Management and Budget to improve agency practices related to program and project management. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the main interagency forum for enhancing agency practices in program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management, reviews high-risk programs identified by the General Accountability Office, and provides recommendations for actions to improve management practices. The Program Management Policy Council advises the Deputy Director for Management, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses workforce development, policy improvement, and agency challenges. The Program Management Policy Council advises on career development, workforce needs, policy improvement, challenges in program management, and governmentwide standards for transparency. They also review information on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Program Management Policy Council advises on governmentwide standards for program management transparency and reviews information on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Program Management Policy Council advises on governmentwide standards for program management transparency and reviews information on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management are key positions within this council. The Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency and other designated federal employees or Armed Forces members are part of the Council. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget serves as the Chairperson, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget serves as the Chairperson of the Council, with a Vice Chairperson elected by members for a term of up to 1 year. The Chairperson presides over meetings, determines the agenda, directs the work of the Council, and establishes subgroups as needed. The Council must meet at least twice per. The Chairperson of the Council, appointed by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, leads meetings, sets the agenda, directs the Council's work, and forms subgroups as necessary. The Council must meet at least twice per fiscal year and can convene at the Chairperson's or majority members' request. Administrative support is provided by agency heads with Project Management Improvement Officers on the Council. The Council, led by the Chairperson appointed by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, meets at least twice per fiscal year. Agency heads with Project Management Improvement Officers on the Council provide administrative support. A report must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with Program Management Improvement Officers, must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The term "agency" in this context excludes the Department of Defense. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, must develop regulations for program and project management personnel standards within 180 days of issuing standards, policies, and guidelines under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations within 180 days to identify key skills and competencies needed for program and project managers in an agency and establish or update job series for program and project management. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations to identify key skills and competencies for program and project managers, establish new job series, and create a career path for managers within agencies. The Government Accountability Office will report on the effectiveness of these policies within 3 years. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies for program and project management within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. A report will examine the effectiveness of standards, policies, guidelines, strategic plans, Program Management Improvement Officers, and the Program Management Policy Council on improving Federal program and project management. 503(c)(1)(H) of title 31, United States Code adds Program Management Improvement Officers and the Program Management Policy Council to improve Federal program and project management.
